abstract.value: Jane LaTouris a journalist, labor activist, and educator living in New York City. She has written for various union publications, managed the Women's Project of the Association for Union Democracy, and wrote the book <emph render="italic">Sisters in the Brotherhoods: Working Women Organizing for Equality in New York City</emph>. She is a two-time winner of the Mary Heaton Vorse Award, the top labor journalism award in New York City. This collection consists of materials created or collected in the course of writing <title>Sisters in the Brotherhoods</title>, and include correspondence with interview subjects, research files, oral history interview transcripts, and manuscripts drafts focused on women in the labor movement, focusing on blue-collar and trade employment. Topics that recur throughout these materials include discimination, welfare, vocational education, and pregnancy as it pertains to working women.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Jane LaTour Papers; WAG 317; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Provenance unknown for materials found in the repository that were added to the collection in 2014. The accession number associated with these materials is 2014.060.

Jane LaTouris a journalist, labor activist, and educator living in New York City. She has written for various union publications, managed the Women's Project of the Association for Union Democracy, and wrote the book <emph render="italic">Sisters in the Brotherhoods: Working Women Organizing for Equality in New York City</emph>. She is a two-time winner of the Mary Heaton Vorse Award, the top labor journalism award in New York City.

The papers of Jane LaTour consist of materials created and collected by LaTour in the course of researching, writing, and discussing her book <emph render="italic">Sisters in the Brotherhoods</emph>. Materials include correspondence with interview subjects, research files, oral history interview transcripts, and manuscripts drafts focused on women in the labor movement, focusing on blue-collar and trade employment. Topics that recur throughout these materials include discimination, welfare, vocational education, and pregnancy as it pertains to working women.

Original Donation1234567Scope and Contents

This series consists of materials created and collected by LaTour in the course of researching, writing, and discussing her book Sisters in the Brotherhoods. Materials include correspondence with interview subjects, research files, oral history interview transcripts, and manuscripts drafts focused on women in the labor movement, focusing on blue-collar and trade employment. Topics that recur throughout these materials include discimination, welfare, vocational education, and pregnancy as it pertains to working women.
